Award.AwardTitle: Identifying cross-disciplinary pathways to translational science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The National Institutes of Health Roadmap places special emphasis on accelerating "bench-to-bedside" research, or the "translation" of basic science research into practical clinical applications, which today typically takes more than 20 years to occur. The nearly $500 million the NIH spends annually on its Clinical and Translational Science Awards (CTSA) program is just one example of the large investments being made to develop a national infrastructure to support translational science. However, tracking the impact of these major policy changes is challenging because although translational science has been described in many different ways, including the frequently used qualitative T1-T4 classification, consensus on a precise definition has not yet been reached. For this reason, it has also been difficult to identify translational science, understand how it occurs, and determine which researchers are conducting it.

Intellectual Merit

This project addresses this problem by building on a recently developed quantitative and visual approach for measuring translation called the Triangle of Biomedicine, which maps biomedical journal articles to a triangle, whose corners represent research related to animals, cells and molecules, and humans. The position of an article on the graph is based on its topics, and translation is defined as movement of a collection of articles, or the articles that cite those articles, towards the human corner. This provides a way of determining the degree to which an individual scientist, organization, funding agency, or scientific field is producing results that have potential impact on human health, and calculating the amount of time it takes. This project extends this Triangle of Biomedicine to another dimension to form a Pyramid of Translation, whose apex represents publications in fields outside of the life and health sciences, including the physical sciences, social sciences, and arts and humanities. This enables researchers to (1) identify citation pathways (one article citing another) and individual researchers that cross in and out of biomedicine, and (2) calculate the frequency that these intersect the shortest paths leading to clinical investigation, giving unprecedented insight to the mechanisms that lead to translation.

Broader Impacts

This project helps policy makers determine the extent to which research outside of biomedicine impacts human health through cross-disciplinary diffusion of knowledge. It gives them a tool not only to evaluate existing investments in translational science, but also to identify non-traditional pathways towards novel therapeutics. More generally, this project demonstrates a technique for discovering where different research domains intersect and measuring the role of cross-disciplinary teams on innovation. It does these using precise quantitative analyses of millions of publications, yet it presents the results in simple data visualizations, which can be understood by both scientists and the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Institutes of Health Roadmap places special emphasis on accelerating "bench-to-bedside" research, or the "translation" of basic science research into practical clinical applications, which today typically takes more than 20 years to occur. The nearly $500 million the NIH spends annually on its Clinical and Translational Science Awards (CTSA) program is just one example of the large investments being made to develop a national infrastructure to support translational science. The goal of this project, "Identifying cross-disciplinary pathways to translational science," was to develop methods to evaluate the impact of these major policy decisions. To do this, we leveraged a quantitative and visual approach for measuring translation that we created called the "Triangle of Biomedicine". It uses a publication's keywords to determine its position along the translational spectrum--a numeric value between 0 (basic science) and 1 (clinical medicine) that we call its "translational index". It also looks at the publications that cite it to determine its influence on subsequent research. With this, we studied two main research questions: First, to what extent does research outside of biomedicine impact human health through cross-disciplinary diffusion of knowledge? Second, do biomedical research teams that include investigators from other disciplines accelerate translation?

 

Our primary source of data was Scopus, a commercial abstract and citation database of peer-reviewed literature, with more than 50 million publications that cover all disciplines. We linked Scopus to PubMed and other databases and applied our Triangle of Biomedicine technique to calculate the degree to which each publication has contributed to research related to human health. We also did the same for each author in Scopus by combining the data on all the publications they wrote.

 

We found that all major non-biomedical fields have at least a small percentage of publications that are biomedical related, though their translational index varies considerably. For example, most biomedical publications in Chemistry are basic science related, while most biomedical publications in the Social Sciences are about clinical medicine. Surprisingly, knowledge from the majority of non-biomedical publications ultimately translates to human-related research, but it usually takes many years and happens indirectly through multiple citation generations (e.g., publication X is cited by publication Y which is cited by publication Z). Counterintuitively, the biomedical publications of authors whose primary research is outside of biomedicine actually translate more often than the biomedical publications of authors who work mainly within biomedicine. Part of the reason is that a large fraction of publications written by biomedical researchers are never cited--the publications are scientific dead ends that never had a chance to translate.

 

As a practical demonstration of our research, we examined the CTSA pilot grant program at Harvard University. In 2009, 458 teams applied for 65 small $50,000 pilot grants to provide seed funding for clinical and translational studies. One of the objectives of the program was to encourage collaboration between basic science researchers and clinical investigators. To determine whether this actually happened, we calculated the translational index range for each team by subtracting the lowest translational index of any person on the team from the highest translational index. As a control group, we also calculated the translational index range of the authors of journal articles that were written at Harvard around the same time. We found that the range of the pilot grant application teams was significantly larger than typical Harvard publications, suggesting that the CTSA program did indeed bring together researchers from different ends of the translational spectrum who would not ordinarily collaborate.

 

Although this project focused on translation to clinical medicine, the methods can be used to study how knowledge crosses any domain. It provides a tool that enables policy makers to trace the complex pathways that lead to scientific discovery and evaluate the impact of investments in science.
